title: Indus Valley Civilization Period
descr: The Indus Valley Civilization developed and flourished in the basin of the Indus River, with evidence of early Hindu practices.

title: Vedic Period Begins
descr: Debate over Aryan migration versus cultural transformation thesis; the composition of the Rig Veda marks the start of the Vedic Age.

title: Upanishads Written
descr: The eleven major Upanishads are written, introducing key Hindu concepts like reincarnation, karma, and moksha.

title: Emergence of Buddhism and Jainism
descr: Buddhism and Jainism break away from the main flow of Hinduism, introducing new spiritual and social ideas.

title: Epic and Puranic Texts
descr: The Epics and Puranas are written, marking the beginning of devotional Hinduism with a focus on deities like Shiva, Vishnu, and Devi.

title: Hindu Response to Buddhism and Jainism
descr: Hinduism evolves in response to Buddhism and Jainism; the Gupta Empire fosters the development of Vaishnavism, Shaivism, and Shaktism.

title: Alexander the Great’s Invasion
descr: Alexander’s invasion introduces Hellenic culture to India, influencing local traditions.

title: Reign of Ashoka
descr: Ashoka's rule leads to the promotion of Dharma and Buddhism, impacting Hinduism.

title: Introduction of Christianity
descr: Christianity is introduced to India, with early presence by Thomas the Apostle and formal establishment by the 6th century CE.

title: Codification of Hindu Laws
descr: Hindu laws are codified, marking a significant development in the legal and social aspects of Hinduism.

title: Gupta Empire
descr: The Gupta Empire's rise ushers in a period of stability and prosperity, leading to the consolidation of Hindu traditions and Sanskrit literature.

title: Fall of Gupta Empire
descr: The Gupta Empire falls, leading to the fragmentation of India into weaker entities.

title: Birth of Adi Sankaracharya
descr: Adi Sankaracharya, a significant philosopher and scholar, is born, introducing important monotheistic beliefs into Hinduism.

title: Bhakti Movements Rise
descr: The Bhakti movement emphasizes devotion to God, responding to various pressures and reforming Hindu practices.

title: Shankara’s Monotheism
descr: Shankara introduces the concept of one Brahman, bringing significant monotheistic beliefs into Hinduism.

title: Queen Sembiyan Madhavi
descr: Queen Sembiyan Madhavi dedicates her life to building Hindu temples and monasteries.

title: Arrival of Islam in India
descr: Islam arrives in India through trade and invasions, including the introduction of Shia Islam and Turkic invasions.

title: European Arrival
descr: Europeans arrive in India, impacting Hindu culture and society with their colonial ambitions.

title: Mogul Emperor Akbar
descr: Akbar's efforts to unite Muslims and Hindus highlight religious tolerance and reform.

title: Hindu Renaissance
descr: The Hindu Renaissance begins, focusing on modern interpretations of Hindu texts and social reform.

title: Jahangir’s Rule
descr: Jahangir’s rule incorporates both Muslim and Hindu teachings.

title: Aurangzeb Outlaws Hindu Worship
descr: Aurangzeb outlaws Hindu worship, leading to forced conversions.

title: Battle of Plassey
descr: Robert Clive's victory at the Battle of Plassey ends the Mogul Empire and establishes British dominance.

title: British Raj Criminalizes Homosexuality
descr: Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code criminalizes homosexual activities under British rule.

title: Paramahansa Ramakrishna
descr: Ramakrishna inspires the Ramakrishna Order; Swami Vivekananda introduces Hinduism to the West.

title: Indian Immigration to Canada
descr: Early immigration of Hindus and Sikhs to Canada begins amidst a hostile environment.

title: Canada’s Immigration Policies
descr: The ‘continuous journey’ legislation effectively bans further Hindu and Sikh immigration to Canada.

title: Era of Mahatma Gandhi
descr: Mahatma Gandhi’s non-cooperation campaign and leadership in Indian nationalism profoundly impact Hinduism.

title: Partition of India
descr: The partition of India creates major upheaval, leading to widespread violence and displacement.

title: Hindu Marriage Act
descr: Enactment of the Hindu Marriage Act and other related laws incorporating Hindu beliefs and practices into Indian law.

title: Migration to the West
descr: Hindu Indians migrate to Britain and North America; Transcendental Meditation and Hare Krishna movement gain global popularity.

title: Indira Gandhi Becomes Prime Minister
descr: Indira Gandhi becomes the first woman Prime Minister of India.

title: Hindu Temple in Manitoba
descr: The Hindu Society of Manitoba opens its first Hindu Temple and Cultural Centre in Winnipeg.

title: Global Hindu Communities
descr: Hindu communities expand globally; significant temples are built around the world.

title: Deepak Obhrai and K. R. Narayanan
descr: Deepak Obhrai becomes the first Hindu-Canadian elected to Canadian Parliament; K. R. Narayanan becomes President of India.

title: Shabnam Mausi Elected
descr: Shabnam Mausi becomes India’s first transgender public official.

title: Kumbh Mela Festival
descr: The Kumbh Mela Festival is recognized as the largest religious gathering in the world.

title: Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in Toronto
descr: The Shri Swaminarayan Mandir is consecrated in Toronto, representing a significant Hindu temple in Canada.

title: Legal Recognition of Same-Sex Marriage
descr: India legalizes same-sex marriage, marking a significant milestone in LGBTQ+ rights.

title: Supreme Court Recognizes Third Gender
descr: India's Supreme Court officially recognizes hijras and other transgender groups as a third gender.

title: Rights of Transgender Persons Bill
descr: The Rights of Transgender Persons Bill is passed, guaranteeing various rights and protections.

title: Hindu Heritage Month in Ontario
descr: Ontario declares October as Hindu Heritage Month, recognizing the contributions of the Hindu community.

title: India Recognizes LGBT Rights
descr: India’s Supreme Court affirms the LGBT community's right to express their sexual orientation and identity.
